caption.title: Schematic of host-virus interactions at the hemagglutinin (HA) viral surface protein.
caption.p: ( A) The structure of the H1N1 HA. The immunodominant HA head (HA1) contains the antigenic sites [ 8] onto which antibodies bind to neutralize the virus, whereas the HA stalk (HA2) is more conserved. ( B) Immune escape due to increased avidity mediated by electrostatic charge, according to transmission experiments by Hensley and coauthors [ 1]. To infect host cells, virions must first successfully enter cells. To accomplish this, the HA protein binds to a cellular receptor, i.e. sialic acid, on the surface of the cell. An increase in charge is posited to increase HA avidity and therefore facilitate HA binding, leading to successful immune escape. ( C) Patterns of charge over time in natural human sequences. Arinaminpathy and Grenfell [ 2] showed that the H3 increases over time, but that the H1 is constant. ( Inset) Schematic of the net charge trends over time for the HAs of H1N1 and H3N2 viruses in natural human sequences.
